prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Statutory basis for assigning a judge

para.paratext: The statute does not give the Panel unlimited power over the assignment of transferred cases to a particular judge. Section 1407(b) of the statute permits the Panel to assign judges to preside over the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with the consent of the transferee district court.[1] In many cases the Panel will assign the transferred cases to a judge without stating reasons for selecting that judge. Most often, however, the judge assigned by the Panel is the judge presiding over the actions pending in the transferee district.

The power of the Panel to assign transferred cases to a judge applies only to judges of the transferee district. The Panel is also authorized to request that the Chief Justice of the United States or Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals having jurisdiction over the transferee district court appoint a district or circuit judge who is not a judge of the transferee district to preside over the pretrial proceedings.[2] The Panel does not frequently use this approach, but has resorted to it when the transferee district suffers from an unusual workload but is otherwise a particularly suitable transferee court.[3]

If a judge from outside the transferee district is appointed he or she may conduct hearings in the transferee district or in the district where he or she is regularly assigned.[4] The Panel has even suggested this procedure as a means of minimizing travel expense.[5]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
